articles.title: Day 1 (Jul 31, 2024)
articles.contents:
Agenda

Time


Session Title


Description


Speakers/Moderators


8:00 AM - 8:30 AM


Registration and Coffee


Welcome remarks by the workshop organizers.




8:30 AM - 8:40 AM


Introduction


Introducion to the workshop.


Spiro Stefanou


8:40 AM - 9:10 AM


Keynote Speaker


Keynote address on recent food price trends.


David Ortega


9:10 AM - 9:40 AM


U.S. Inflation in the Context of International Price Changes


Speaker on international food price trends and how they impact U.S. inflation.


John Baffes


9:40 AM - 10:10 AM


Policy Responses to Food Price Inflation


Discussion on monitoring and addressing food price inflation.


Seth Meyer


10:10 AM - 10:30 AM


Moderated Discussion/Q&A


Recap of presentations given by speakers for sessions 1-3.


Spiro Stefanou, David Ortega, John Baffes, and Seth Meyer


10:30 AM - 10:45 AM


Break






10:45 AM - 11:45 AM


Retrospective Analysis on Food Price Inflation


Examination of retrospective data related to food price inflation and identification of price drivers.


Michael Adjemian, Francisco Scott, Metin Çakir


11:45 AM - 1:00 PM


Lunch Break






1:00 PM - 2:15 PM


Methods for Evaluating and Forecasting Food Price Changes


Overview of different forecasts and methods used by organizations like Food Price Outlook, MTED, and RRED and uses across governments, industry, and the public.


Matthew MacLachlan, Raghav Goyal, Aparna Mathur, Aaron Smith


2:15 PM - 2:30 PM


Break






2:30 PM - 3:30 PM


Understanding Determinants of Food Prices for Forecasting


Research presentations highlighting research to improve food price forecasting, including leading indicators of food price changes, energy prices, and factors driving prices in specific markets including beef and seafood.


Matthew MacLachlan, Kaitlyn Malakoff, Jude Bayham, Xiaoli Etienne


3:30 PM - 3:45 PM


Break






3:45 PM - 4:45 PM


Impacts of Food Price Changes


Presentation on the impacts of food price inflation on price markups, consumer welfare, and food security.


Lauren Chenarides, Julian Alston, Anne Byrne


4:45 PM - 5:00 PM


Concluding Remarks


Recap of day 1 sessions and what to expect for day 2.




5:00 PM - 6:00 PM


Networking Reception


Join us for a networking reception located in the hotel. For dinner recommendations near the hotel, please visit the Places page on the workshop website.








Back to Home

articles.title: Day 2 (August 1, 2024)
articles.contents:
Agenda

Time


Session Title


Description


Speakers/Moderators


8:30 AM - 9:30 AM


Public Data Resources


Overview of publicly available data resources related to food price inflation, including BLS Consumer Price Index (CPI), USDA Food-at-Home Monthly Area Prices (F-MAP), and BEA Personal Consumer Expenditures (PCE). How to access and utilize these resources effectively.


Steve Reed, Ana Aizcorbe, Megan Sweitzer


9:30 AM - 9:45 AM


Break






9:45 AM - 10:45 AM


Private Data Collection and Research


Presentation from industry experts on private data collection methods and their contribution to understanding food price trends. Discussion on the challenges and opportunities in utilizing private data for research purposes.


Catherine Cullinane-Thomas, Mary Muth, Leo Feler, Doug Edmonds


10:45 AM - 12:00 PM


Breakout Sessions


Participants will be divided into smaller groups to discuss and identify stakeholders’ needs, underutilized information, and potential improvements in evaluating and forecasting food prices.


Facilitators include: Ana Aizcorbe, John Baffes, Jude Bayham, Anne Byrne, Metin Çakir, Kailin Kroetz, James MacDonald, Matthew Maclachlan, Abigail Okrent, Aaron Smith, Simon Somogyi, and Chen Zhen


12:00 PM - 12:30 PM


Closing Remarks


Recap of the workshop and information about the upcoming special issue.








Back to Home

articles.title:
Workshop on Food Prices and Forecasting Sponsored by ERS (PC52)
https://bit.ly/3Lm9zX8
articles.contents:
PC52: Workshop on Food Prices and Forecasting
          
          
          Home
          Day 1
          Day 2
          Discussion Topics
          Special Issue
          People
          Places
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Workshop on Food Prices and Forecasting Sponsored by
ERS (PC52)https://bit.ly/3Lm9zX8
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                        2024 AAEA Annual Meeting
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Food Price Outlook
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        GitHub Repo
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            
            About this Workshop
            Description  Increases in food price
            inflation and volatility in recent years have renewed focus
            on the determinants and impacts of food price changes, as
            well as on the importance of reliable food price forecasts.
            The USDA Food Price Outlook (FPO) tracks and forecasts food
            price changes and FPO forecasts inform USDA agencies,
            industry, academia, and the public and rank second in web
            traffic among ERS data products. Even after recent
            refinements, the current FPO approach to forecasting food
            prices could be further improved by incorporating market
            conditions such as energy costs, wages, labor availability,
            transportation congestion, and market concentration, which
            have recently been cited as drivers of record-breaking
            inflation rates. Macroeconomic conditions that potentially
            affect retail demand, including the money supply, exchange
            rates, and core inflation, have only been examined in a
            pre-pandemic context, and it is unclear whether these same
            mechanisms can explain current inflationary trends. To
            address these shortcomings and identify new research areas,
            the workshop will gather top experts from government,
            academia, and industry to identify stakeholders’ needs,
            underutilized information, and the best methods for
            evaluating and forecasting food prices.
            Target Audience  Empirical
            researchers from government, academia, and industry in
            evaluating and forecasting food prices.
            Expected Outcomes  The workshop’s
            main goals are to present and discuss the research that has
            been developed under the Strategic Priority Grant on the
            topic of food prices and forecasting that was sponsored by
            the USDA-ERS, foster the establishment of research
            partnerships between attendees, and to gather papers for the
            publication of a journal special issue.
            
            
            Event Details
            Wednesday,
            July 31, 2024, 8:00AM - 6:00PM

              About this Workshop
              Description  Increases in food
              price inflation and volatility in recent years have
              renewed focus on the determinants and impacts of food
              price changes, as well as on the importance of reliable
              food price forecasts. The USDA Food Price Outlook (FPO)
              tracks and forecasts food price changes and FPO forecasts
              inform USDA agencies, industry, academia, and the public
              and rank second in web traffic among ERS data products.
              Even after recent refinements, the current FPO approach to
              forecasting food prices could be further improved by
              incorporating market conditions such as energy costs,
              wages, labor availability, transportation congestion, and
              market concentration, which have recently been cited as
              drivers of record-breaking inflation rates. Macroeconomic
              conditions that potentially affect retail demand,
              including the money supply, exchange rates, and core
              inflation, have only been examined in a pre-pandemic
              context, and it is unclear whether these same mechanisms
              can explain current inflationary trends. To address these
              shortcomings and identify new research areas, the workshop
              will gather top experts from government, academia, and
              industry to identify stakeholders’ needs, underutilized
              information, and the best methods for evaluating and
              forecasting food prices.
              Target Audience  Empirical
              researchers from government, academia, and industry in
              evaluating and forecasting food prices.
              Expected Outcomes  The workshop’s
              main goals are to present and discuss the research that
              has been developed under the Strategic Priority Grant on
              the topic of food prices and forecasting that was
              sponsored by the USDA-ERS, foster the establishment of
              research partnerships between attendees, and to gather
              papers for the publication of a journal special issue.

articles.title: Day 2 - Breakout Sessions
articles.contents:
Attendees will be divided into groups of 6 to 7 participants with a mix of university faculty, graduate students, government employees, and private sector professionals to discuss and identify stakeholders’ needs, underutilized information, and potential improvements in evaluating and forecasting food prices.

Discussion topics

Topic


Discussants


Concentration and IO


James MacDonald (Group 1), Metin Çakir (Group 2)


Forecasting


Aaron Smith (Group 3), Matthew MacLachlan (Group 4)


Impacts of Price Changes


Anne Byrne (Group 5), Abigail Okrent (Group 6)


Input Price Pass-Through


Jude Bayham (Group 7), Kailin Kroetz (Group 8)


International Markets


Simon Somogyi (Group 9), John Baffes (Group 10)


Price Indexes


Chen Zhen (Group 11), Ana Aizcorbe (Group 12)
